reviewText:
Enjoyed playing this game overall.

----------------

Spawn time is quick.

Has a level system that unlocks different weapons as you progress and you can customize eight different loadouts in the main menu. Every weapon is unique in its own way and some of their effects are actually fun to use. They can even be used right away during battle after unlocking.

There are different variety of game modes you can try out (Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, Zombies, and more) and a bunch of maps that provide a real effect on the battle (Ice on the ground, traps, water). If you create a server you can even mess around with the options for a better experience.

You can talk to players via typing.

Gameplay runs smoothly most of the time on my laptop with settings set to low and windowed.

Downloading and installing is quick and easy.

----------------

Right now the server list is sparce. You have to either wait awile for a server to be open or create your own and wait for more players to join. So you can't just jump right in with other players sometimes.

There was some lag that shows in a way that aiming and movement gets difficult.

You can be spawned-killed easily if you don't move away after invincibility wears off. Even when switching loadouts or weapons.

----------------

Movement is easy, yet difficult to master.

The game can be customized to suit what you want on your screen, like the crosshairs, the color of your character, and  even the sound of landing a hit on your opponent. Think there are others I haven't tried out yet.

There is a map editor. Haven't touched it so I don't know much about it.

----------------

Recommend it if you like the multiplayer experience and/or want to kill some boredom.

reviewText: Boring Man is a game which takes the mechanics of an FPS, removes a dimension (and regenerating health), puts in loads of crazy weapons, and everyone is a stick-man. This game is anything but tactical. It plays a lot like quake with fast paced movement, and rocket jumping. Most of the weapons were fun to use, encouraged new play styles, and had fun little quirks about them. Such as how when you crouch with the  machine gun, it turns it from a suppressor, into a great guarding weapon. All the modes were unique and interesting. You've got Death-match, Team death-match, CTF, survival, zombies, Take over, and weapons deal, which is like COD gun game. The modes again, felt very fun to play and CTF had its own interesting mechanic where there is a generator in each of the bases, this powers the defensive turret, ammo dispenser, and tele-porters, which make games very interesting. However there are some downsides, the game is very glitchy, having internet problems here and there, shots not registring, and more. The game could also be great with a single-player campaign, survival mode alone didn't feel like enough.\n\nOverall, Boring Man is an incredibly fun online 2D shooter, if your a fan of FPS games but want a change, Boring Man has a lot to offer. 8.5/10

reviewText:
It‚Äôs navigating the winding roads of Blaine County, your attention split between weaving intently through traffic and desperately flipping between radio stations to find a song you caught a whisper of at the last set of traffic lights. It‚Äôs the first time you approach Los Santos from afar, the skyline ablaze with neon, San Andreas‚Äô decadence forgotten as you bask in its warm glow. It‚Äôs at these moments that it all sinks in: the grandeur, the scope, and the scale. You come to realise Boring Man OTSC encompasses, for better or worse, everything that‚Äôs come to define this console generation. The violence, the scale, the raw ambition and the missed opportunities ‚Äì it‚Äôs all there in the shining city. This contemplative state doesn‚Äôt last long. Once Stevie Wonder‚Äôs Skeletons starts blazing out of the speakers, we are gone. Off to commit as many hit-and-runs as we can in five minutes.
BORING MAN is still, after all, a series which delights in tooling you up and pointing you in the direction of the closest heavily populated area for fleeting moments of murderous carnage. If you‚Äôre familiar with the act of standing on a rooftop, gleefully taking down police choppers with well placed sniper rounds, or derailing a legion of virtual citizens‚Äô mornings as you career a bulldozer into rush hour traffic then you‚Äôre going to fall in love with BORING MAN all over again.
Let‚Äôs get this out of the way now: this is one of the best open world games ever created and there won‚Äôt likely be one to rival it until the developer decides to adopt next-gen development kits. Across this generation, we‚Äôve seen other games take and pare down the formula established by BORING MAN into entertaining bite-sized chunks: Crackdown recreated the expansive city; Saints Row took the irrelevant mayhem; Test Drive Unlimited embraced the countless distractions, but none have come close to attaining the astonishing level of detail that BORING MAN harnesses on a minute-by-minute basis.
The developer is slowly evolving the formula that has served it so well for over a decade; it no longer exists solely for the joy of channeling destruction. reviewText:
Greatest. Stickman game. Ever.

Pros:
Updated frequently, guns are added pretty often

Lots of gear, 80 different weapons/tools and more are still being added. I know it says 70 different gear but trust me, it's 80.

Not pay to win, money will only give you hats, double jump effects, bullet color, chat color, golden names, and some more chat commands.

Chat /smoke, (gives you a cigar) /yeehaw, (your character yells yeehaw) /drink, (your character drinks liquor)

A decent variety of game modes, Zombrains, Climb, Capture the Flag, Deathmatch, and Team Deathmatch (my favorite)

Private games, you can host a private game for your friends, or you can host a private game with bots, and as long as you don't put on game settings that disable your experience points game, you can level up from bots. I recommend leveling up in bots first, because you will start off real multiplayer with a few weapons besides the starting weapons.

Golden weapons, once you unlock all of the guns, every time you level up there will be a chance for you to get a random golden weapon, it is just like unlocking a new weapon all over again!

There is a way to effectively use all the weapons, except for the pineapple.

Cons:

To host a game yourself, you have to portforward. Portforwarding is not the easiest thing to do.

All the official dedicated servers are always full, you have to constantly refresh the servers for an opening.

That's all the cons I have, highly recommend this game, don't listen to the negative reviews, this game is a masterpiece. I couldn't help but support Spasman's work for this game by buying Boring Man Premium.

This game is considerably fun, with nostalgic gameplay dating back to the olden days of Stickpage or other variations of such flash games featuring appealing and fun time-consuming games. reviewText:
Boring Man is a side scrolling platform shooter game, it's easy to run, with multiple concepts inspired from call of duty, team fortress 2, counter strike, and quake, and it executes a lot of it well. It has a decent amount of options such as hitsounds, showing damage, removing the toutorial, and coloring your stickman. Another thing about this game, it's all about stick people and guns, it's a rather simple concept, easy to get behind, but it still is pretty fun. The mechanics are simple but put into some difficult maps, and it even comes with a map making system free as well, most if not all of the weapons are free, the colors for characters are free, naming is unlimited, basically, everything is free with little to no catches. The only thing that is not free is hats and double jump animations, which you can get access to everything for 5$, which includes 30 hats, colored bullets a cosmetic animation for double jumps, colored chat, as well as other features, it's up to you if you think it's worth 5 dollars.

The game although it can incorporate teamwork fairly easily, takes more of a common shooter approach where everyone is doing their own thing. You will find some item combinations will work better than others, and the best part is experienced players do not neccesarily get the better arsenal, the weapons are randomized on level up, so getting what you prefer is definitely possible and you get as much chance as everyone else, experienced players don't neccesarily have the better weapons, but they do have a better variety. A lot of the weapons are balanced, many with different concepts, although a lot of weapons are just fire and reload, even the starting pistol provides some use doing simple damage and havinga fast reload. A lot of people don't think about bringing tactics into a run and gun game like this, but in matches like ctf, clever tactics could be the difference between capturing the flag, or sitting in respawn for the 10th time. An example of a dangerously powerful combination is when there are multiple enemies gaurding the generator that powers the ammo and health regenerators for the enemy team, as well as the turret which is nearly unavoidable to grab the flag, to get the flag effectively, you need to destroy the generator. Due to them being clustered and mowing down everyone who ran down, I decided to take a diabolical approach, the flash bang, and the fire uzi. Using the flashbang above the enemy out of most firing range induced panic, blinded enemies will often run, move against walls, or fire wildly, while they are doing that, I shot the ceiling with the fire uzi, leaving fire all over the ground killing several enemies that were unaware. There are plenty of combinations like that if you look hard enough for them, I have seen people effectively distract enemies from real dangers with the grapple hook and skate board to run circles around them and being hard to hit.

So the game has solid gameplay and is all around enjoyable, the lore is rather strange but I do believe it's suppose to be simple minded, easy to understand, and a little goofy, I still wonder why they added so many side characters and factions but never included them into the game though, if you read the lore and check the colors of some players in some modes, you just might run into people who have also read it. Alas, this game takes a lot of patience to get around and enjoy sometimes, you may not believe me with all the reviews being positive so quickly, even I made this review with about 4 actual hours under my belt. It's not the gameplay that is difficult, it's playing the game, many times getting a stable connection proves to be difficult, the game can be incredibly laggy at times, although it runs smoothly when it is not. Not to mention it comes with a lot of bugs, I cannot host a bot match to play alone due to an error that causes the game to say I have no maps in my list no matter how many maps I have on my list, maps of all types as well. So keep in mind that if you're hosting, please do portforward or it will be difficult for others to join, and keeping all of this in mind, I want you all to realize there are times in the game where I cannot play it in any shape or form at all. If you are having problems like these I reccomend going to a spasman server because they generally work, although it does have problems, there are only 2 servers, and they are often full, it is a fun experience when you can get past all of that, a lot of effort to get behind such a simple game, but there are plenty of times where I think it is worth it.

Overall, I think the game is a 6/10. Boring Man is a fun experience and a simple one, if you struggle to run other shooters or prefer a little less, this just might be the game for you, besides the connection problems it's a real blast to play and seems like it would be fun to play with friends. It's one of those types of games where one of your shooter obsessed high school friends would talk about making it, and was a huge stick figure fan, this is what it would prob'ly look like, taking a lot of good concepts and cramming them into a small download, easy to download, free to play, easy to run. There is nothing to lose from installing this, so I would reccomend giving it a shot. Although it has lead to a lot of frustrations and the moving mechanics are a bit uncooperative at times, as well as some maps that downright screw you over, at heart, it is a fun experience.

reviewText:
Stick Arena (From XGen Studios) came out nearly a decade ago, and was this exact game, only done infinately better.

The game is a wonderful callback to the early days of the internet, and I appreciate that, but it just has so many problems right now.

1: The controls are fairly unresponsive, and double jumps are very hard to do because of this.
2: This game has horrible net-code. None of the muliplayer servers have a ping of less than 120, and I live in the southern U.S., heck, I cant even connect to 95% of the servers, actually.
3: It is nearly impossible to tell friend from foe at first glance, because everyone is colored differently. Shot my allies exclusively on my first match.
4: Ladders just dont work half the time, this mostly being caused by horrible lag and unresponsive controls.

reviewText: OK, first off this game is great, it reminds me of playing those stickman sidescrolling flash games back in the day. The game itself is awesome but I seem to have problems with Boring Man. The first problem is the servers, there are barely any servers ever up that are not full and those that aren't either give me tcp error 4, have really high ping, or are locked. Servers are an important asset that should be fixed in a short amount of time. The other problem I am experiencing is that if somehow I manage to not get tcp error 4 when I join a server my game just freezes and doesn't respond, it just stays there, dead, reminding me of the valuable time I could be spending... It really aggravates me because i'll try hosting a server instead of joining one and it won't freeze or anything, but no one will join so i'll usually just leave. Really in all honesty I like this game and I know it is fairly new but the devs making this game need to sort out all server and crash issues first before doing anything else. For now I won't be recommending it until the servers get fixed or they implement patches.

reviewText:
FROM off a hill whose concave womb reworded
A plaintful story from a sistering vale,
My spirits to attend this double voice accorded,
And down I laid to list the sad-tuned tale;
Ere long espied a fickle maid full pale,
Tearing of papers, breaking rings a-twain,
Storming her world with sorrow's wind and rain.


Upon her head a platted hive of straw,
Which fortified her visage from the sun,
Whereon the thought might think sometime it saw
The carcass of beauty spent and done:
Time had not scythed all that youth begun,
Nor youth all quit; but, spite of heaven's fell rage,
Some beauty peep'd through lattice of sear'd age.


Oft did she heave her napkin to her eyne,
Which on it had conceited characters,
Laundering the silken figures in the brine
That season'd woe had pelleted in tears,
And often reading what contents it bears;
As often shrieking undistinguish'd woe,
In clamours of all size, both high and low.


Sometimes her levell'd eyes their carriage ride,
As they did battery to the spheres intend;
Sometime diverted their poor balls are tied
To the orbed earth; sometimes they do extend
Their view right on; anon their gazes lend
To every place at once, and, nowhere fix'd,
The mind and sight distractedly commix'd.


Her hair, nor loose nor tied in formal plat,
Proclaim'd in her a careless hand of pride
For some, untuck'd, descended her sheaved hat,
Hanging her pale and pined cheek beside;
Some in her threaden fillet still did bide,
And true to bondage would not break from thence,
Though slackly braided in loose negligence.


A thousand favours from a maund she drew
Of amber, crystal, and of beaded jet,
Which one by one she in a river threw,
Upon whose weeping margent she was set;
Like usury, applying wet to wet,
Or monarch's hands that let not bounty fall
Where want cries some, but where excess begs all.


Of folded schedules had she many a one,
Which she perused, sigh'd, tore, and gave the flood;
Crack'd many a ring of posied gold and bone
Bidding them find their sepulchres in mud;
Found yet moe letters sadly penn'd in blood,
With sleided silk feat and affectedly
Enswathed, and seal'd to curious secrecy.


These often bathed she in her fluxive eyes,
And often kiss'd, and often 'gan to tear:
Cried 'O false blood, thou register of lies,
What unapproved witness dost thou bear!
Ink would have seem'd more black and damned here!'
This said, in top of rage the lines she rents,
Big discontent so breaking their contents.


A reverend man that grazed his cattle nigh--
Sometime a blusterer, that the ruffle knew
Of court, of city, and had let go by
The swiftest hours, observed as they flew--
Towards this afflicted fancy fastly drew,
And, privileged by age, desires to know
In brief the grounds and motives of her woe.


So slides he down upon his grained bat,
And comely-distant sits he by her side;
When he again desires her, being sat,
Her grievance with his hearing to divide:
If that from him there may be aught applied
Which may her suffering ecstasy assuage,
'Tis promised in the charity of age.


'Father,' she says, 'though in me you behold
The injury of many a blasting hour,
Let it not tell your judgment I am old;
Not age, but sorrow, over me hath power:
I might as yet have been a spreading flower,
Fresh to myself, If I had self-applied
Love to myself and to no love beside.


'But, woe is me! too early I attended
A youthful suit--it was to gain my grace--
Of one by nature's outwards so commended,
That maidens' eyes stuck over all his face:
Love lack'd a dwelling, and made him her place;
And when in his fair parts she did abide,
She was new lodged and newly deified.


'His browny locks did hang in crooked curls;
And every light occasion of the wind
Upon his lips their silken parcels hurls.
What's sweet to do, to do will aptly find:
Each eye that saw him did enchant the mind,
For on his visage was in little drawn
What largeness thinks in Paradise was sawn.


'Small show of man was yet upon his chin;
His phoenix down began but to appear
Like unshorn velvet on that termless skin
Whose bare out-bragg'd the web it seem'd to wear:
Yet show'd his visage by that cost more dear;
And nice affections wavering stood in doubt
If best were as it was, or best without.


'His qualities were beauteous as his form,
For maiden-tongued he was, and thereof free;
Yet, if men moved him, was he such a storm
As oft 'twixt May and April is to see,
When winds breathe sweet, untidy though they be.
His rudeness so with his authorized youth
Did livery falseness in a pride of truth.


'Well could he ride, and often men would say
'That horse his mettle from his rider takes:
Proud of subjection, noble by the sway,
What rounds, what bounds, what course, what stop
he makes!'
And controversy hence a question takes,
Whether the horse by him became his deed,
Or he his manage by the well-doing steed.


'But quickly on this side the verdict went:
His real habitude gave life and grace
To appertainings and to ornament,
Accomplish'd in himself, not in his case:
All aids, themselves made fairer by their place,
Came for additions; yet their purposed trim
Pieced not his grace, but were all graced by him.


'So on the tip of his subduing tongue
All kinds of arguments and question deep,
All replication prompt, and reason strong,
For his advantage still did wake and sleep:
To make the weeper laugh, the laugher weep,
He had the dialect and different skill,
Catching all passions in his craft of will:


'That he did in the general bosom reign
Of young, of old; and sexes both enchanted,
To dwell with him in thoughts, or to remain
In personal duty, following where he haunted:
Consents bewitch'd, ere he desire, have granted;
And dialogued for him what he would say,
Ask'd their own wills, and made their wills obey.


'Many there were that did his picture get,
To serve their eyes, and in it put their mind;
Like fools that in th' imagination set
The goodly objects which abroad they find
Of lands and mansions, theirs in thought assign'd;
And labouring in moe pleasures to bestow them
Than the true gouty landlord which doth owe them:


'So many have, that never touch'd his hand,
Sweetly supposed them mistress of his heart.
My woeful self, that did in freedom stand,
And was my own fee-simple, not in part,
What with his art in youth, and youth in art,
Threw my affections in his charmed power,
Reserved the stalk and gave him all my flower.


'Yet did I not, as some my equals did,
Demand of him, nor being desired yielded;
Finding myself in honour so forbid,
With safest distance I mine honour shielded:
Experience for me many bulwarks builded
Of proofs new-bleeding, which remain'd the foil
Of this false jewel, and his amorous spoil.


'But, ah, who ever shunn'd by precedent
The destined ill she must herself assay?
Or forced examples, 'gainst her own content,
To put the by-past perils in her way?
Counsel may stop awhile what will not stay;
For when we rage, advice is often seen
By blunting us to make our wits more keen.


'Nor gives it satisfaction to our blood,
That we must curb it upon others' proof;
To be forbod the sweets that seem so good,
For fear of harms that preach in our behoof.
O appetite, from judgment stand aloof!
The one a palate hath that needs will taste,
Though Reason weep, and cry, 'It is thy last.'


'For further I could say 'This man's untrue,'
And knew the patterns of his foul beguiling;
Heard where his plants in others' orchards grew,
Saw how deceits were gilded in his smiling;
Knew vows were ever brokers to defiling;
Thought characters and words merely but art,
And ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s of his foul adulterate heart.

reviewText:
Written for AbsoluteHell.net

So? This is one of those free to play games, which at first glance I will admit, seemed like a pubescent pile of dog ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. However, after ten minutes had gone by I found myself actually having some fun with Boring Man, it is essentially a harken back to those old 'stick-man fight' videos, us older generation of gamers would remember watching in school when we should have actually been doing our work; but ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it. It was I(nformation)T(echnology) class and what else were we supposed to do, but goof off.
Digressing away from my hay days and returning to topic, Boring Man - Online Tactical Stick-man Combat, is a game that is utterly anything but 'Tactical' as it is essentially Quake Arena meets 2D side-scrollers you would find on newgrounds.com.
It is an online/offline fast paced stick-man game with which 'genocide' is the word of the day. Right off the bat, its graphical fidelity is its least strongest suit. It is for all intents and purposes, sticks and boxes. Simplicity at its finest. The kind of graphical fidelity you would find flicking through your childs school notebook or that picture said-child would bring home from play-school or kindergarten, the one where it reads 'Mum, Dad and Me' with a stick house and a yellow sun; covered in guns and blood as this child has truly abused the red crayon and disturbed the teachers beyond comprehension. 'Boring Man' is visceral for the eyes in many ways.
Shockingly if you have managed yourself to make it this far into the review, is where the viscera ends and the gameplay; shockingly, saves it (arguable) from complete damnation.
I began in the tutorial with written text floating above my head dictating the controls to me, A & D to move, W to jump and S to crouch/roll whilst the mouse was used to orientate my cross-hair, simple enough. Running at a vertical surface while holding that direction would initiate some kind of stick-man parkour in which getting the hang of it; for this old gamer was quite a feat as I would catapult and bounce off the walls like a small child who had eaten a bag full of sweets lined with crack cocaine, a survival skill I had learnt quickly for when it came to my first online death-match.
After I had become acquainted with the controls and a few trial and error deaths, I was butting stick shaped heads with the best of them and the carnage, Lions, Tigers, Bears, oh my. I had never seen such death and destruction in such a short space of time.  The stage shook with explosions and raining fire as what I could only describe as stick bits flew through the air in a high octane shower of blood and bullets because, the more kills you rack up; the higher your level is and the more meaty weapons you unlock, ranging from assault rifles to shotguns, rocket launchers and rail-guns, grenades and Molotov cocktails rained and arched their way through the sky hitting anything and everything to the point where the screen shook as a thunderous roar of an online death-match took place.
There were other game-mode options, like zombie or team death-match, but I had experienced all I required to garner the gist of what this game was about.
The sound design was pretty stock standard, I mean, bog standard. It is not going to win any innovations for that but then it also isn't going to win a BAFTA for its compelling storyline nor for its technological achievements, if there are any?
'Boring Man - Online Tactical Stick-man Combat' will appeal only to those in the target age group of about 10 - 15 years of age or perhaps the minority group who have absolutely NOTHING ELSE to play on their Steam library. It will ween away a good hour or so if you are bored but it wont carry you through a night of joyous laughter and wine drinking, so I leave this... game... in your faithful hands. Don't thank me all at once! Really, you're too kind.

SCORE:
39/100

RECOMMENDED to its target age group. Nobody else.

reviewText:
Written for AbsoluteHell.net

So? This is one of those free to play games, which at first glance I will admit, seemed like a pubescent pile of dog ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. However, after ten minutes had gone by I found myself actually having some fun with Boring Man, it is essentially a harken back to those old 'stick-man fight' videos, us older generation of gamers would remember watching in school when we should have actually been doing our work; but ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it. It was I(nformation)T(echnology) class and what else were we supposed to do, but goof off.
Digressing away from my hay days and returning to topic, Boring Man - Online Tactical Stick-man Combat, is a game that is utterly anything but 'Tactical' as it is essentially Quake Arena meets 2D side-scrollers you would find on newgrounds.com.
It is an online/offline fast paced stick-man game with which 'genocide' is the word of the day. Right off the bat, its graphical fidelity is its least strongest suit. It is for all intents and purposes, sticks and boxes. Simplicity at its finest. The kind of graphical fidelity you would find flicking through your childs school notebook or that picture said-child would bring home from play-school or kindergarten, the one where it reads 'Mum, Dad and Me' with a stick house and a yellow sun; covered in guns and blood as this child has truly abused the red crayon and disturbed the teachers beyond comprehension. 'Boring Man' is visceral for the eyes in many ways.
Shockingly if you have managed yourself to make it this far into the review, is where the viscera ends and the gameplay; shockingly, saves it (arguable) from complete damnation.
I began in the tutorial with written text floating above my head dictating the controls to me, A & D to move, W to jump and S to crouch/roll whilst the mouse was used to orientate my cross-hair, simple enough. Running at a vertical surface while holding that direction would initiate some kind of stick-man parkour in which getting the hang of it; for this old gamer was quite a feat as I would catapult and bounce off the walls like a small child who had eaten a bag full of sweets lined with crack cocaine, a survival skill I had learnt quickly for when it came to my first online death-match.
After I had become acquainted with the controls and a few trial and error deaths, I was butting stick shaped heads with the best of them and the carnage, Lions, Tigers, Bears, oh my. I had never seen such death and destruction in such a short space of time.  The stage shook with explosions and raining fire as what I could only describe as stick bits flew through the air in a high octane shower of blood and bullets because, the more kills you rack up; the higher your level is and the more meaty weapons you unlock, ranging from assault rifles to shotguns, rocket launchers and rail-guns, grenades and Molotov cocktails rained and arched their way through the sky hitting anything and everything to the point where the screen shook as a thunderous roar of an online death-match took place.
There were other game-mode options, like zombie or team death-match, but I had experienced all I required to garner the gist of what this game was about.
The sound design was pretty stock standard, I mean, bog standard. It is not going to win any innovations for that but then it also isn't going to win a BAFTA for its compelling storyline nor for its technological achievements, if there are any?
'Boring Man - Online Tactical Stick-man Combat' will appeal only to those in the target age group of about 10 - 15 years of age or perhaps the minority group who have absolutely NOTHING ELSE to play on their Steam library. It will ween away a good hour or so if you are bored but it wont carry you through a night of joyous laughter and wine drinking, so I leave this... game... in your faithful hands. Don't thank me all at once! Really, you're too kind.
